REL101.name: Exploring Religion
REL101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL101.description: Religion and religions as historical phenomena. Non-textual and textual religions. Theories of the origins and functions of religion. Exemplary voices from various traditions examined in their historical and doctrinal settings.

REL150.name: Introduction to Biblical Literature
REL150.description: A critical survey of biblical texts, including the Hebrew Bible, the New Testament, and writings found in the Apocrypha/Deuterocanon, that combines historical and literary analysis with attention to the ancient religious context of this literature.

REL175.name: Religion in Film
REL175.description: Film representation of religions and spiritual traditions through their representations in film.

REL185.name: Introduction to Religion and Nonprofits
REL185.description: History, themes and issues in the intersection of religion, philanthropy, and nonprofit organizations in U.S. and global contexts.

REL205.name: Myth, Self, and Religion
REL205.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL205.description: The mythic quest for meaning, identity, value, and transcendence as seen through religious biography and literary narrative. Myth in relation to religious symbols and life-cycle rituals. Cross-cultural perspective on religious world views and the interpretation of myth as sacred narrative.

REL210.name: Religion and the Environment
REL210.description: Global perspectives on religion and the environment, with U.S. emphasis. Focus on places, beliefs, practices, and conflicts. Field trips required.

REL215.name: The Sound Of World Religions: Music, Chant, and Dance
REL215.description: Introduction to the lived experience of world religions through investigation of their sacred songs.

REL220.name: Religion in America
REL220.description: History, themes and issues of religions in America from precolonial times to the present.

REL260.name: Philosophy of Religion
REL260.description: Key concepts, themes, and questions in the philosophy of religion.

REL275.name: Magic and Mysticism: An Introduction to Esoteric Religion
REL275.description: Surveys esoteric traditions in Europe, England and North America including alchemy, magic, Jewish and Christian mysticisms, and secret or semisecret groups like Freemasonry. Transdisciplinary investigation of religion, science, literature, art and history.

REL290.name: Independent Study
REL290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL290.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

REL291.name: Special Topics in Religious Studies
REL291.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL291.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings, proposed by faculty on a group basis.

REL294.name: History of Catholicism, Late Antiquity to the Present
REL294.description: Roman Catholicism. Changing structures of administration, instruments of repression, and responses to and impact on social, cultural and political transformations. Missionary movements, orders and councils.

REL301.name: Methods and Theories in the Study of Religion
REL301.description: Introduction to prominent methods and theories through which religions and religious phenomena can be understood.

REL306.name: Native American Religions
REL306.description: Indigenous forms of spirituality among the Native American peoples. Materials from myth, ritual, ceremonial life, and art as ways of obtaining and sharing religious knowledge. Pervasive spiritual and cosmological themes.

REL307.name: Shamanism
REL307.description: Shamanic practice in different cultural and religious contexts. Entheogens. Peyote, psilocybin. Healing, sacred knowledge, spiritual journeys, sacred space, presence in world religions, patterns of pilgrimage, theoretical debates regarding shamanism and entheogens.

REL310.name: Judaism
REL310.description: Jewish life, thought, and institutions. Jewish calendar. Second Temple and Rabbinic periods. Talmud and Midrash. Jewish life in Europe and America. Hasidic, Reform, Orthodox, and Conservative movements. Anti-Semitism, Zionism, and the Holocaust. Current issues.

REL320.name: Christianity
REL320.description: Origins and historical development of Christianity. Rituals, institutional forms (Eastern Orthodox, Catholic, Protestant). Monastic and mendicant movements. Major doctrines and their development. Contemporary status and role.

REL325.name: East Asian Buddhism
REL325.description: Buddhist traditions of East Asia, including China, Tibet, Korea, and Japan, as well as Mahayana and Vajrayana.
REL325.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL330.name: Islam
REL330.description: Islam from the time of Muhammad to the present. Pre-modern developments. Life of Muhammad. Qur'an, Hadith, and Islamic law. Sunnis, Shiites, sects, and their rituals. Unity and diversity. Modern movements and trends.

REL335.name: East Asian Religions
REL335.description: Religious traditions of East Asia, including China, Korea, and Japan.

REL340.name: Hinduism
REL340.description: Historical, philosophical and doctrinal development. Vedic Sacrifice, Upanishads, Samkhya-Yoga and Vedanta, Vaishnavism, Shaivism, Shaktism, and modern Hinduism.
REL340.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL345.name: Religions of South Asia
REL345.description: Historical, philosophical, and doctrinal development of Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism, North Indian Islam, and Sikhism.
REL345.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL350.name: Buddhism in South Asia
REL350.description: Early origins of Buddhism. Life of the Buddha. Formulation of the Samgha. Pali canon. Three turnings of the Wheel of the Law. Monastic developments vs. lay Buddhism. Buddhist meditation practices.

REL355.name: Southeast Asian Religions
REL355.description: Southeast Asia as a religious and cultural crossroads. The historic mix of Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Christianity, and Chinese religions. Diversity of indigenous animistic religions. Past and present relations between religions and the state.

REL360.name: African Religion
REL360.description: Variant forms of the religions of Africa. Indigenous African religions examined through their mythology, rituals, symbols, and social consequences. Islam and Christianity. Interaction between religion and politics.

REL365.name: Evangelicalism in the U.S.
REL365.description: History, culture, beliefs, and practices of American evangelicalism.

REL380.name: New Religions
REL380.description: New religious movements, groups and individuals seen historically. Major controversies.

REL385.name: Religion, Health, and Healthcare
REL385.description: Religion, health, and illness, and responses to them in health care professions, faith communities, and the broader society. Topics may include religion and interpretations of embodiment or suffering; challenges of religious diversity to health care professionals; and the "religiosity" of secular science, medicine, and public health, which are partially shaped by their own myths, rituals, and symbols.

REL411.name: Modern Jewish Thought (W)
REL411.description: Representative Jewish thought from the Enlightenment to the present. Authors such as Moses Mendelssohn, Abraham Geiger, Leo Pinsker, Hermann Cohen, Franz Rosenzweig, Ahad Ha-Am, Martin Buber, Mordecai Kaplan, A. I. Heschel, and Emil Fackenheim.
REL411.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
REL411.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

REL412.name: Jewish Mysticism (W)
REL412.description: Introduction to the doctrines, ritual practices, and history of Jewish mysticism.
REL412.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL413.name: Jewish Philosophy (W)
REL413.description: Introduction to the history of Jewish philosophy.
REL413.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL414.name: Jewish Identity (W)
REL414.description: Major themes and aspects of Jewish identity in modernity. Topics including philosophy, food, education, material culture.
REL414.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL420.name: Birth of Christianity (W)
REL420.description: The historical setting and types and meaning of the text of the New Testament explored through various techniques of historical, literary, and textual analysis.
REL420.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
REL420.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

REL425.name: Apocalypse Then and Now (W)
REL425.description: Apocalyptic thought and writings in ancient Christianity and the persistence of apocalyptic ideas in modern fiction and film.
REL425.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
REL425.restrictions: Not open to freshmen and not open to sophomores.

REL430.name: The Qur'an and Its Interpreters (W)
REL430.description: The historical setting, types and topics of the Quranic text, and an overview of the history of its interpretation.
REL430.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL432.name: Modern Muslim Thought (W)
REL432.description: Representative Muslim thinkers and intellectual trends from the 19th century to the present. Focus on issues such as social order, the role of Islamic law, pluralism and gender.
REL432.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL441.name: Devotional Hinduism (W)
REL441.description: Historical, philosophical, and doctrinal development of Bhakti Hinduism (devotional Hinduism) of North India from the 12th to the 18th century.
REL441.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL460.name: Advanced Topics in the Philosophy of Religion (W)
REL460.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL460.description: In-depth investigation focused on specific themes on figures in the philosophy of religion such as notions of divinity, the rationality of belief, philosophy under religious authority, conceptions of human perfection.
REL460.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
REL460.restrictions: Not open to freshmen and not open to sophomores.

REL461.name: South Asian Religions and Bollywood Film (W)
REL461.description: Religion, culture and film in South Asia. Bollywood (Indian) films, with special focus on religion, gender, and globalization.
REL461.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL480.name: Comparative Studies in Religion (W)
REL480.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL480.description: Multidisciplinary approaches to topics such as patterns in comparative religion, comparative mysticism, or comparative mythology.
REL480.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
REL480.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

REL485.name: Religion and Nonprofit Leadership (W)
REL485.description: Religion, ethical leadership practices, and nonprofit organizations in both religious and secular contexts.
REL485.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL490.name: Independent Study (W)
REL490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL490.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
REL490.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL491.name: Special Topics in Religious Studies (W)
REL491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL491.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings, proposed by faculty on a group study basis.
REL491.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
REL491.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

REL493.name: Religious Studies Internship
REL493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL493.description: Supervised pre-professional experience related to religious studies.
REL493.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

REL499.name: Senior Thesis or Project (W)
REL499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL499.description: Individual research project supervised by a faculty member that demonstrates the student's ability to do independent research.
REL499.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

REL890.name: Independent Study
REL890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
REL890.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

REL891.name: Special Topics in Religious Studies
REL891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
REL891.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty for graduate students on a group study basis.
